8.title: Geauga Park District planning three Sundays for the annual Sap’s-a-Risin’ celebration
8.snippet: Geauga Park District's tradition of free maple sugaring events at Swine Creek Reservation in Middlefield will continue with the annual Sap's-a-Risin'...
8.content:
Geauga Park District’s tradition of free maple sugaring events at Swine Creek Reservation in Middlefield will continue with the annual Sap’s-a-Risin’ celebration.

Festivities on three Sundays – Feb. 23, March 2 and March 9, all from noon to 4 p.m. – include sap-gathering in the sugarbush with a horse-drawn sap sled, sugar house tours with sample tastes of fresh syrup, and historical stations with costumed interpreters displaying and demonstrating maple sugaring methods from prehistoric to modern day, according to a news release.

Also, attendees can visit Swine Creek Lodge to warm up with free maple treats and live music — the Raccoon County Ramblers on Feb. 23, Mr. Haney String Band on March 2, and The Real Deal String Band on March 9. Maple syrup produced right onsite will also be available for sale as supplies last, the release stated.

Visitors stopping at the event can also make a day of it to see other sugaring operations in the area. Swine Creek Reservation is a featured stop on two drive-it-yourself tours on March 2 and 9: the Ohio Maple Producers’ Maple Madness Tour and the more local Maple Tour of Northeast Ohio.

Tour maps with complete lists of participating sugar houses are available at ohiomaple.org and mpneoh.com.

9.title: AI Agents Take Center Stage: Workday, ServiceNow, and SAP Challenge Agentforce
9.snippet: A deep dive into the enterprise AI agent race, analyzing how Salesforce, Workday, ServiceNow, and SAP are shaping AI-driven automation.
9.content:
December 2024 witnessed a landmark moment in enterprise AI: the announcement of Salesforce Agentforce 2.0. Amid a flurry of AI agent launches from Workday, ServiceNow, and SAP, Salesforce took center stage, redefining the conversation around AI-driven business automation. At the Agentforce 2.0 event, Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff declared, “The AI revolution isn’t coming—it’s here.” With its pre-trained autonomous agents, low-code Agentforce Builder, and deep integration with Salesforce Data Cloud and Slack, Agentforce 2.0 cemented Salesforce’s position as the leader in AI-powered digital workforces.

But Salesforce isn’t the only major player in this space. Since December, Workday, ServiceNow, and SAP have been rolling out their own AI-powered agents, each claiming to revolutionize how businesses operate. Here’s how these platforms compare in the battle for AI agent supremacy.

Workday’s AI Agent Strategy: HR & Finance Automation

Workday’s AI ambitions center on HR and finance, where it already serves as the system of record for workforce data. Its latest innovation, the Workday Agent System of Record, provides a governance framework for both human employees and AI-powered agents, ensuring seamless automation. More significantly, Workday is pioneering role-based AI agent descriptions, enabling enterprises to define and standardize AI agent roles for enhanced discovery, selection, and composition. This framework allows AI agents to integrate into structured workforce environments with predefined capabilities, much like APIs for enterprise automation.

Workday’s role-based AI agents include:

Contracts Agent : Extracts key obligations from contracts and automates follow-ups.

: Extracts key obligations from contracts and automates follow-ups. Payroll Agent : Monitors payroll transactions and flags anomalies in real time.

: Monitors payroll transactions and flags anomalies in real time. Policy Agent: Enforces HR policies and provides proactive guidance.

By leveraging Workday Illuminate, its AI platform that processes over 800 billion transactions annually, Workday ensures its AI agents are deeply embedded in HR and finance operations. Furthermore, Workday’s role-based metadata standardization could shape the future of enterprise AI marketplaces, much like standardized APIs transformed software integration. This approach contrasts with Salesforce Agentforce’s more customer-facing automation focus.

ServiceNow’s AI Agent Strategy: Enterprise Workflow Orchestration

ServiceNow is positioning itself as the control tower for AI agents across IT, customer service, and HR workflows. Its AI Agent Orchestrator and AI Agent Studio empower organizations to:

Coordinate multiple AI agents across different business units.

across different business units. Build custom AI agents with a no-code interface .

with a . Deploy pre-built AI agents that integrate with ITSM, HR, and security workflows.

ServiceNow’s Workflow Data Fabric ensures AI agents have real-time access to enterprise-wide data. Unlike Salesforce Agentforce, which enhances CRM workflows, ServiceNow’s focus is on cross-functional enterprise automation, particularly in IT service management (ITSM).

SAP’s AI Agent Strategy: Enterprise-Wide AI & Data Governance

SAP is embedding AI across its massive ERP footprint, with Joule AI agents driving automation across finance, supply chain, HR, and customer service. Key differentiators include:

SAP Business Data Cloud : A unified data platform integrating SAP and non-SAP data.

: A unified data platform integrating SAP and non-SAP data. SAP Knowledge Graph : Context-aware AI reasoning across enterprise processes.

: Context-aware AI reasoning across enterprise processes. AI Agent Builder: Low-code tools for creating industry-specific AI agents.

SAP’s strength lies in its ability to link AI agents across business processes—from procurement to order-to-cash—whereas Salesforce Agentforce excels in sales, service, and marketing automation.

How Salesforce Agentforce 2.0 Stands Apart

While Workday, ServiceNow, and SAP focus on back-office automation, Salesforce Agentforce is built for customer-facing AI workflows. Its key features include:

Pre-trained AI Agents : Industry-specific AI agents ready to automate sales, service, and marketing tasks.

: Industry-specific AI agents ready to automate sales, service, and marketing tasks. Agentforce Builder : Low-code customization tools.

: Low-code customization tools. Slack Integration : AI agents embedded in Slack for real-time collaboration .

: AI agents embedded in . Salesforce Data Cloud: AI agents act on real-time customer data.

Competitive Breakdown: Where Each Vendor Stands

Let’s take a look at how these vendor strategies compare.

Vendor Primary AI Agent Focus Data Foundation Key Differentiator Salesforce CRM & Customer Engagement Salesforce Data Cloud Deep CRM integration & Slack capabilities Workday HR & Finance Automation Workday Illuminate Governance of AI agents in workforce management & Role-based AI metadata ServiceNow IT & Workflow Automation Workflow Data Fabric Multi-agent orchestration across business units SAP End-to-End Business Processes SAP Business Data Cloud & Knowledge Graph Cross-functional AI agents spanning multiple SAP modules

The Future of AI Agent Interoperability

As enterprise AI adoption accelerates, organizations will increasingly rely on AI agents from multiple vendors to streamline workflows, automate decisions, and enhance business agility. While today’s AI-powered platforms—Salesforce Agentforce, Workday AI Agents, ServiceNow AI Orchestration, and SAP Joule—largely operate within their respective ecosystems, the industry is moving toward a future where AI agents from different vendors collaborate seamlessly across enterprise functions.

This AI Agent Workflow Diagram illustrates how enterprise AI agents from Workday, ServiceNow, and Salesforce could interact with HR, IT, and sales functions. The sequence diagram showcases AI-driven automation in payroll processing, IT service management, and customer engagement, highlighting seamless data flow across ERP, CRM, and enterprise data cloud systems. Source: SalesforceDevops.net

To illustrate this vision, we present the following diagram, which imagines a multivendor AI agent ecosystem where intelligent agents work together to fulfill distinct enterprise roles. In this scenario:

HR Managers leverage Workday AI Agents to automate payroll processing, enforce policies, and ensure compliance, while connecting with financial systems via ERP.

to automate payroll processing, enforce policies, and ensure compliance, while connecting with financial systems via ERP. IT Administrators rely on ServiceNow AI Orchestration to manage IT support tickets, predict infrastructure failures, and ensure system security, with real-time insights from enterprise data clouds.

to manage IT support tickets, predict infrastructure failures, and ensure system security, with real-time insights from enterprise data clouds. Sales Representatives use Salesforce AI Agents to retrieve customer insights, personalize engagement, and drive revenue growth through CRM-integrated automation.

These AI agents don’t just execute tasks—they communicate, share insights, and adapt in real time to enterprise needs. In a fully interoperable landscape, AI agents could dynamically integrate with multiple systems, exchanging structured knowledge through standardized frameworks. This level of cooperation would enable enterprises to:

Reduce silos by creating a network of AI-driven assistants across business units.

by creating a network of AI-driven assistants across business units. Improve decision-making with AI agents that analyze and respond to cross-functional data.

with AI agents that analyze and respond to cross-functional data. Enhance efficiency through automation that is not limited by vendor ecosystems.

The Embedded AI Agent Battle Is Just Beginning

While we are still in the early stages of AI agent adoption, companies are already laying the groundwork for this future. As vendors refine their agent architectures, interoperability will be key to unlocking the full potential of AI-driven automation. The race is on to define the standards, governance, and technical frameworks that will bring this multivendor AI agent landscape to life.

Each vendor is leveraging its system-of-record dominance to deliver AI agents that streamline workflows. While Salesforce is pushing AI-powered digital workers for front-office automation, Workday is focusing on AI governance in HR/Finance, ServiceNow is orchestrating AI-driven ITSM, and SAP is embedding AI across enterprise operations.

What’s Next?

2025 will reveal how enterprises adopt these AI agents. Will companies embrace multiple AI agent platforms, or will one vendor dominate enterprise AI automation?

One thing is clear: the age of AI-powered digital workers is here, and the battle for AI agent supremacy is just beginning.

Moreover, Salesforce and Workday have a history of technical alliance announcements, signaling potential for deeper collaboration. Adam Evans, Salesforce AI GM, in a recent press release, explicitly endorsed Workday’s agentefforts, reinforcing the strategic importance of standardized AI agent definitions. This alignment could pave the way for enhanced AI agent interoperability across platforms and accelerate the evolution of enterprise AI marketplaces, where role-based agents are seamlessly discoverable, composable, and deployable.

0.title: SAP Proposes Dividend of €2.35 per Share
0.snippet: The recommended dividend for 2024 for SAP shareholders is an increase of €0.15, or 6.8% compared to the dividend paid for fiscal year 2023.
0.content:
WALLDORF — The Supervisory Board and Executive Board of SAP SE (NYSE: SAP) recommend that shareholders approve a dividend of €2.35 per share for fiscal year 2024. This is an increase of €0.15, or 6.8% compared to the dividend paid for fiscal year 2023 (€2.20).

If approved by shareholders and assuming the same level of treasury shares at the time of SAP SE’s Annual General Meeting of Shareholders on May 13, 2025, and as at December 31, 2024, the total amount distributed in dividends would be approximately €2.741 billion (2023: €2.565 billion), representing a pay-out ratio of 51.9% (2023: 43.0%).

SAP believes that its shareholders should benefit appropriately from the profit the Company made in 2024. The Company’s dividend policy is to pay a dividend totaling at least 40% of non-IFRS profit after tax from continuing operations.

The following dates are relevant for the dividend payment:

Record date for dividend payment: May 13, 2025

Ex-dividend date: May 14, 2025

Payment date: May 16, 2025

Note to holders of SAP ADRs (American Depositary Receipts):

One SAP ADR represents one SAP SE share. The final dividend amount per ADR is dependent upon the euro/U.S. dollar exchange rate. Since SAP SE pays cash dividends on the ordinary shares in euro, the exchange rate fluctuations will affect the U.S. dollar amounts received by holders of ADRs. The final dividend payment by SAP SE to the depositary bank is scheduled for May 16, 2025. The depositary bank will then convert the dividend payment from euro into U.S. dollars as promptly as practicable.

Visit the SAP News Center. Follow SAP at @SAPNews.

About SAP

As a global leader in enterprise applications and business AI, SAP (NYSE: SAP) stands at the nexus of business and technology. For over 50 years, organizations have trusted SAP to bring out their best by uniting business-critical operations spanning finance, procurement, HR, supply chain, and customer experience. For more information, visit www.sap.com.

To preview and download broadcast-standard stock footage and press photos digitally, please visit www.sap.com/photos. On this platform, you can find high resolution material for your media channels.

1.title: SAP taps Splunk’s Simon Davies to lead reorg’d APAC region
1.snippet: Paul Marriott passes the helm to the former Splunk exec who had previous stints with Salesforce and Microsoft in the region. SAP Simon Davies.
1.content:
SAP has announced the appointment of Simon Davies as president of the company’s newly reorganized Asia Pacific (APAC) region. Based in Singapore, Simon Davies will be responsible for SAP’s strategy, operations, people, sales, services, partnerships and profitability in the region, including the markets of Korea, Australia, New Zealand, India, Japan, Greater China, and Southeast Asia.

As president, Davies will manage more than 31,000 employees across 78 offices. SAP currently serves major customers in the region, including Hyundai Motor Co., Kia Motors, NEC, Coles Group, Wipro, Fujitsu, Shiseido, Himalaya, Cochlear, and Japan Airlines.

According to SAP, Mr. Davies has been instrumental in developing, selling, and implementing IT solutions in the Asia Pacific region for 25 years, working with leading software companies such as Microsoft, Salesforce, and Oracle. He most recently served as senior vice president and general manager for Asia Pacific and Japan at Splunk for over three years.

3.title: Inspired Education expands SAP partnership to implement AI HR system for 14,000 employees
3.snippet: Inspired Education renews its SAP partnership to integrate AI-powered HR solutions for 14000 employees across its global schools. The deployment of SAP...
3.content:
SAP and Inspired Education have renewed their partnership to introduce AI-driven HR solutions for 14,000 employees worldwide.

Inspired Education, which operates 120 private schools for over 95,000 students across six continents, will implement SAP SuccessFactors and SAP’s AI copilot, Joule, to support recruitment, employee retention, and HR efficiency.

AI integration in HR operations

With 60% of its employees being teachers, Inspired Education required a centralized HR system to streamline its global workforce management. The renewed partnership with SAP, which has been in place for five years, will focus on automating HR processes, improving recruitment, and using AI for data-driven decision-making.

SAP’s AI-powered HR tools will assist in performance management, benefits administration, and employee training. The introduction of self-service HR functionality will reduce manual administrative tasks, allowing HR teams to focus on operational strategy.

Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, will be integrated into Inspired Education’s recruitment and HR management. The tool will analyze CVs, match candidates to job profiles, and generate interview questions and assessment tasks, optimizing the hiring process across multiple regions.

Joule will also be used to track employee performance metrics, providing data for performance reviews, training programs, and internal mobility. The system will support HR teams in developing career progression plans and structuring benefit programs.

Leila Romane, Managing Director, SAP UK and Ireland, said:

"Our partnership with Inspired Education continues to go from strength to strength. Global organizations need access to real-time data insights to deliver value to their employees. With SAP SuccessFactors and the deployment of our copilot, Joule, we are driving genuine transformation that will see Inspired Education better understand its workforce, how they operate, produce better talent recruitment and retention strategies, whilst reducing heavy administrative processes. We’ll continue to work together to ensure Inspired Education remains at the forefront of educational excellence."

Implementation of SAP SuccessFactors

Inspired Education will introduce SAP SuccessFactors in multiple stages over three years. The initial phase includes Employee Central, Performance, and Recruiting modules, with Onboarding, Compensation, and Workforce Analytics scheduled for later implementation.

The rollout plan allows Inspired Education to customize the platform for its global workforce while ensuring compliance with local employment regulations. The multi-language functionality of SAP SuccessFactors will help support staff across different regions.

Torben Lundberg, Chief Information Officer, Inspired Education, added:

"We are committed to providing a premium educational experience for all 95,000 of our students, and our teachers and staff are key to this ambition. As an organization, we recognized the need for a unified HR platform that could bring together our operations worldwide and drive out inefficiencies, increasing internal mobility and empowering our staff to do what they do best without unnecessary burden. SAP SuccessFactors will support us through our work in transforming our processes and workflows through digital tools."

5.title: SAP (ETR:SAP) Has A Rock Solid Balance Sheet
5.snippet: Howard Marks put it nicely when he said that, rather than worrying about share price volatility, 'The possibility of permanent loss is the risk I worry...
5.content:
Howard Marks put it nicely when he said that, rather than worrying about share price volatility, 'The possibility of permanent loss is the risk I worry about... and every practical investor I know worries about.' When we think about how risky a company is, we always like to look at its use of debt, since debt overload can lead to ruin. We note that SAP SE ( ) does have debt on its balance sheet. But should shareholders be worried about its use of debt?

What Risk Does Debt Bring?

Debt assists a business until the business has trouble paying it off, either with new capital or with free cash flow. If things get really bad, the lenders can take control of the business. However, a more common (but still painful) scenario is that it has to raise new equity capital at a low price, thus permanently diluting shareholders. Of course, plenty of companies use debt to fund growth, without any negative consequences. The first thing to do when considering how much debt a business uses is to look at its cash and debt together.

How Much Debt Does SAP Carry?

As you can see below, at the end of December 2024, SAP had €11.4b of debt, up from €7.17b a year ago. Click the image for more detail. On the flip side, it has €11.2b in cash leading to net debt of about €208.0m.

A Look At SAP's Liabilities

We can see from the most recent balance sheet that SAP had liabilities of €19.1b falling due within a year, and liabilities of €9.24b due beyond that. On the other hand, it had cash of €11.2b and €7.48b worth of receivables due within a year. So its liabilities outweigh the sum of its cash and (near-term) receivables by €9.60b.

Since publicly traded SAP shares are worth a very impressive total of €321.4b, it seems unlikely that this level of liabilities would be a major threat. Having said that, it's clear that we should continue to monitor its balance sheet, lest it change for the worse. But either way, SAP has virtually no net debt, so it's fair to say it does not have a heavy debt load!

We use two main ratios to inform us about debt levels relative to earnings. The first is net debt divided by earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA), while the second is how many times its earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) covers its interest expense (or its interest cover, for short). This way, we consider both the absolute quantum of the debt, as well as the interest rates paid on it.

SAP has barely any net debt, as demonstrated by its net debt to EBITDA ratio of only 0.022. Happily, it actually managed to receive more interest than it paid, over the last year. So it's fair to say it can handle debt like an Olympic ice-skater handles a pirouette. Another good sign is that SAP has been able to increase its EBIT by 26% in twelve months, making it easier to pay down debt. There's no doubt that we learn most about debt from the balance sheet. But ultimately the future profitability of the business will decide if SAP can strengthen its balance sheet over time. So if you want to see what the professionals think, you might find to be interesting.

Finally, while the tax-man may adore accounting profits, lenders only accept cold hard cash. So it's worth checking how much of that EBIT is backed by free cash flow. During the last three years, SAP produced sturdy free cash flow equating to 70% of its EBIT, about what we'd expect. This free cash flow puts the company in a good position to pay down debt, when appropriate.

Our View

SAP's interest cover suggests it can handle its debt as easily as Cristiano Ronaldo could score a goal against an under 14's goalkeeper. And the good news does not stop there, as its net debt to EBITDA also supports that impression! Overall, we don't think SAP is taking any bad risks, as its debt load seems modest. So the balance sheet looks pretty healthy, to us. When analysing debt levels, the balance sheet is the obvious place to start. However, not all investment risk resides within the balance sheet - far from it. To that end, you should be aware of the .

If you're interested in investing in businesses that can grow profits without the burden of debt, then check out this free .

6.title: CxO Decision Brief: SAP Build
6.snippet: SAP Build takes an innovative approach to enterprise application development by combining Joule, an AI-powered development tool, with the Cloud Application...
6.content:
Organizations with limited experience in the SAP ecosystem may face a steeper learning curve during initial adoption. Teams heavily invested in diverse technology stacks should carefully plan integration strategies. The platform’s comprehensive nature may present complexity challenges for smaller development teams without proper training and support.

Adoption streamlines application development workflows by reducing reliance on senior developers while preserving enterprise-grade quality. Organizations can expect faster project delivery using lower-skilled resources, though initial training on SAP-specific tools is required. IT organizations benefit from standardized development patterns and reduced maintenance, thanks to CAP’s built-in best practices.

Development time directly impacts market competitiveness and operational costs. As business demands rapidly outpace IT budgets and development resources, these tools can serve as a differentiator, enabling teams to meet and exceed goals. Each month of delay brings missed market opportunities, mounting technical debt, and increasing strain on limited developer resources.

By leveraging CAP, the advantages of faster application development and reduced development effort extend beyond deployment to reduce the full lifecycle costs of enterprise development.

SAP Build takes an innovative approach to enterprise application development by combining Joule, an AI-powered development tool, with the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) to deliver a unified platform that accelerates development while enforcing enterprise-grade best practices and standardization.

1. Solution Value

Today’s enterprises struggle to deliver business-critical applications amid scarce senior developer resources and mounting technical debt. Traditional development approaches require extensive coordination between business units and development teams, creating bottlenecks that delay digital transformation initiatives and slow market responsiveness.

SAP Build transforms this landscape by combining the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) with AI-powered development tools. In benchmark testing, the platform demonstrated extraordinary efficiency gains: 3x greater development velocity and a 59% reduction in overall workload compared to traditional approaches.

By providing pre-built components, standardized patterns, and automated testing tools, SAP Build enables organizations to accelerate development while maintaining enterprise-grade quality. The platform’s integration with SAP systems and AI-assisted development (including for mobile) has shown particular strength in reducing time on task, with time spent on specific actions cut by 30%. Most significantly, these gains are achieved while reducing dependency on senior developers—allowing organizations to scale their development capacity without compromising standards or accumulating technical debt.

2. Urgency and Risk

Scarcity of experienced developers, particularly senior-level talent where salaries have risen over 25% since 2021, and mounting technical debt force organizations to make critical decisions about their application development strategies. The growing compensation requirements for senior developers, now averaging $150,000-$175,000 annually in major markets, combined with fierce competition for their skills, intensifies the need for solutions that can effectively leverage junior and mid-level talent. Delays in modernizing development practices directly impact market competitiveness and operational costs.

Urgency

SAP Build effectively addresses escalating development resource constraints through its AI-assisted development environment and Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). The benchmark study validates this approach, demonstrating that SAP Build requires 59% less development effort than traditional methods and improves development velocity by 3x.

For enterprises, these efficiency gains translate to immediate business impact:

Industries with customer-facing requirements like financial services, retail, utilities, and telecommunications can deploy new features in days instead of weeks.

Industries dependent on supply chain efficiency like manufacturing, consumer goods, natural resources, and logistics can adapt rapidly to market changes without waiting for senior developer availability.

Organizations across all sectors reduce technical debt through standardized development patterns, automated quality controls and declarative programming models.

Organizations that delay adoption face quantifiable costs. GigaOm’s analysis shows that traditional approaches consume 3x more weighted development effort while delivering slower results. This resource drain grows more acute as senior developer availability decreases and technical debt compounds.

Risk

While SAP Build’s comprehensive platform accelerates development, organizations must manage specific implementation risks. These risks, identified as part of GigaOm’s benchmark analysis, impact both development and technical integration and must be carefully planned for using SAP’s extensive support resources, including:

SAP Learning Hub for structured training paths

Technical documentation and implementation guides

Developer tutorials and how-to videos

SAP community support forums

Direct access to SAP experts through standard support channels and partners

Implementation best practices and reference architectures

Organizations can leverage these resources to mitigate common risks around developer onboarding, system integration, and deployment planning.

Development Impacts

Initial velocity slightly decreases during the 4-6 week platform onboarding period, after which velocity increases.

Teams require structured training on CAP development patterns and SAP ecosystem concepts. Because CAP is built on Java and JavaScript, developers can leverage their existing Java/JavaScript expertise.

Junior developers need guidance transitioning from traditional frameworks to SAP Build’s development model.

Technical Integration Challenges

Organizations running diverse technology stacks should plan their API and data integration points, though the SAP BTP integration suite makes this effort much easier.

Existing custom frameworks may require refactoring to align with CAP architectural patterns.

Applications with complex third-party integrations need additional testing and validation. Again, SAP BTP can be applied to manage this challenge.

Risk Mitigation Activities

Commit to a phased deployment starting with smaller applications.

Establish dedicated training programs aligned with team size and expertise.

Adopt parallel development approaches during the transition period.

Define clear governance for maintaining compliance and security standards.

SAP offers support working with its clients developing a center of excellence in SAP Build.

3. Benefits

SAP Build combines AI-assisted development with the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) to revolutionize enterprise application delivery. The benchmark study demonstrates concrete improvements in speed, quality, and resource utilization that translate directly to business value:

Development velocity: Teams achieve a dramatic 3x improvement in overall development velocity compared to custom approaches. This dramatic gain impacts delivery time and enables organizations to respond more quickly to market opportunities and business demands.

Teams achieve a dramatic 3x improvement in overall development velocity compared to custom approaches. This dramatic gain impacts delivery time and enables organizations to respond more quickly to market opportunities and business demands. Resource optimization: The platform delivers a 59% reduction in total development effort through automated processes and AI assistance. This efficiency gain allows organizations to complete projects with fewer senior developer resources while maintaining quality standards.

The platform delivers a 59% reduction in total development effort through automated processes and AI assistance. This efficiency gain allows organizations to complete projects with fewer senior developer resources while maintaining quality standards. AI-powered efficiency: The integrated Joule copilot AI assistant can automate tasks and and improve both speed and consistency of development while reducing the burden on development teams.

The integrated Joule copilot AI assistant can automate tasks and and improve both speed and consistency of development while reducing the burden on development teams. Lifecycle impact: The advantages of faster application development and reduced development effort extend beyond deployment. By leveraging CAP, applications require significantly less code compared to custom approaches, easing development and reducing the burden of maintenance throughout the application’s lifecycle. This streamlined codebase not only minimizes technical debt, it enhances long-term efficiency and cost-effectiveness.

4. Best Practices

To fully leverage SAP Build, organizations should adopt a structured implementation approach that prioritizes proper environment setup and team enablement. The benchmark study revealed that teams achieved optimal results when following a methodical adoption path that balanced quick wins with sustainable development practices. Consider these proven implementation guidelines:

Environment setup and training: Invest in comprehensive training on both SAP Build and the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), as understanding these foundations significantly impacts team productivity.

Invest in comprehensive training on both SAP Build and the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), as understanding these foundations significantly impacts team productivity. Phased implementation strategy: Begin with smaller, non-critical applications to build team confidence and expertise. The study showed that teams who started with complex projects faced steeper learning curves and longer time-to-value.

Begin with smaller, non-critical applications to build team confidence and expertise. The study showed that teams who started with complex projects faced steeper learning curves and longer time-to-value. AI implementation governance: Establish clear processes for reviewing and validating AI-generated code. While the Joule AI assistant can accelerate key development tasks (such as code generation, unit test creation, and synthetic test data creation) by up to 30%, teams need structured validation procedures to maintain code quality and security standards.

Establish clear processes for reviewing and validating AI-generated code. While the Joule AI assistant can accelerate key development tasks (such as code generation, unit test creation, and synthetic test data creation) by up to 30%, teams need structured validation procedures to maintain code quality and security standards. Integration planning: Develop a clear strategy for connecting with existing systems and data sources. Teams in the benchmark study who planned their integration approach early avoided significant deployment delays and security concerns.

Develop a clear strategy for connecting with existing systems and data sources. Teams in the benchmark study who planned their integration approach early avoided significant deployment delays and security concerns. Quality assurance process: Implement regular code reviews and testing protocols. The benchmark revealed that teams using SAP Build’s built-in testing tools achieved more consistent quality outcomes with fewer senior developer resources.

5. Organizational Impact

SAP Build adoption affects workflows across development, operations, and business teams. The benchmark study indicates successful implementations follow a structured approach over three distinct phases of learn, develop, and iterate.

Learn: The initial transition (weeks 1-6) focuses on core platform skills and process alignment. Development teams learn the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) methodology while operations teams adapt deployment procedures. Business units revise their requirements and feedback processes to match the platform’s accelerated development cycle.

Develop: As teams gain proficiency, the 3x increase in development velocity drives operational changes. Project managers adjust estimation models, security teams implement standardized compliance checks, and business units compress feedback cycles. These changes enable faster feature delivery while maintaining consistent quality and security controls.

Iterate: Teams experience compounding efficiency gains as they master the capabilities of SAP Build. Development teams leverage advanced CAP features and reusable components while operations teams streamline deployment pipelines. Business analysts accelerate validation through direct prototyping, while Joule AI, trained specifically on SAP data and processes, helps all teams optimize their development workflows. SAP BTP services create opportunities to integrate with lines of business to amplify impact over time.

People Impact

The platform reshapes traditional development roles. Junior developers take on more complex tasks through guided frameworks, while senior developers shift focus to architecture and innovation. The benchmark showed a 59% reduction in development effort, allowing teams to complete more projects without additional staffing. Training costs peak during the first quarter but decrease significantly as teams master the platform.

Investment Outlook

SAP Build follows a dual licensing model through the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP): user-based licensing and runtime-based licensing. This hybrid approach provides cost optimization flexibility—organizations pay for developer access during development while production costs scale with actual application usage. A typical enterprise implementation starts with licensing for core development teams (10-15 users), while production costs are optimized based on actual usage.

Implementation costs include:

Initial platform licensing

Training program development

System integration services across platforms and ecosystems

Infrastructure adjustments

Ongoing support and maintenance

The benchmark study indicates that organizations should budget for 4-6 weeks of reduced team velocity during initial implementation. However, the documented 3x advantage in development efficiency typically offsets these costs within the first year of operation.

6. Solution Timeline

Implementing SAP Build can vary depending on the complexity of the projects, the size of the development team, and the organization’s familiarity with the SAP ecosystem. Organizations that take on the initial setup and onboarding process themselves can expect the work to take a few weeks to a few months. This includes setting up the development environment, training developers on the platform and CAP, and integrating with existing systems. Note that SAP offers services that can significantly reduce this time expectation. Ongoing optimization and further integration may require additional time and resources as the organization gains more experience with the platform. Factors such as the complexity of the application being developed and the level of customization required can also impact the timeline.

Future Considerations

Over the next three years, organizations can anticipate SAP Build to further mature and evolve, with enhancements in AI capabilities, expanded language support, and deeper integration with the SAP ecosystem. SAP’s roadmap likely includes advancements in areas such as intelligent code completion, automated testing, and improved developer collaboration tools. As the low-code/no-code and pro-code markets grow, SAP Build is well-positioned to be a vital tool for organizations seeking to accelerate application development and drive digital transformation.

7. Analyst’s Take

Enterprise application development platforms are evolving to address the fundamental challenges of developer scarcity and accelerating business demands. SAP Build stands out in this market through its combination of AI-assisted development and the Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). The benchmark study validates this approach, showing 3x greater development velocity and a 59% reduction in overall development effort.

The platform is particularly effective for organizations that prioritize standardized development practices and maintain significant SAP investments. Its comprehensive approach to enterprise application development provides clear advantages for teams seeking to reduce technical debt while accelerating delivery.

Two factors require attention during adoption: integration planning for organizations with diverse technology stacks and structured training programs to ensure team readiness. Organizations that address these elements systematically typically see positive returns within the first quarter of implementation.

8. About GigaOm

GigaOm provides technical, operational, and business advice for IT’s strategic digital enterprise and business initiatives. Enterprise business leaders, CIOs, and technology organizations partner with GigaOm for practical, actionable, strategic, and visionary advice for modernizing and transforming their business. GigaOm’s advice empowers enterprises to successfully compete in an increasingly complicated business atmosphere that requires a solid understanding of constantly changing customer demands.

GigaOm works directly with enterprises both inside and outside of the IT organization to apply proven research and methodologies designed to avoid pitfalls and roadblocks while balancing risk and innovation. Research methodologies include but are not limited to adoption and benchmarking surveys, use cases, interviews, ROI/TCO, market landscapes, strategic trends, and technical benchmarks. Our analysts possess 20+ years of experience advising a spectrum of clients from early adopters to mainstream enterprises.

GigaOm’s perspective is that of the unbiased enterprise practitioner. Through this perspective, GigaOm connects with engaged and loyal subscribers on a deep and meaningful level.

8.title: Over-performing SAP business and getting aggressive with gen AI pay off for Hackett Group as "budgeted buyers" get ready to spend in 2025
8.snippet: Will 2025 be the year when buyers with allocated spend step up to the mark to take gen AI advisory services mainstream? CEO Ted Fernandez is a believer.
8.content:
Over-performance in its SAP solutions arm and an “aggressive pivot” towards higher margin generative AI consulting drove Hackett Group to full year revenues of $313.9 million for 2024, up from $296.6 million in 2023.

Q4 revenue was $79.235 million, up from $72.4 million a year earlier. That said, net income for the full year was down from $34.2 million to $29.6 million and for Q4 from $7.85 million to $3.56 million. CEO Ted Fernandez knows where to look for the growth drivers here:

Our results were driven by the over-performance of our SAP segment and the strong performance of our GSBT (Global Strategy and Business Transformation) segment, which continues to see increased revenue growth from our gen AI engagements. Gen AI revenues have a higher margin than our traditional consulting and implementation revenues and are driven by the highly-differentiated capabilities of our AI XPLR, X-P-L-R, platform and our recently acquired ZBrain platform, as well as the LeewayHertz implementation team.

For context, Hackett’s SAP Solutions business saw a 51% increase in revenues year-on-year, compared to a six percent decrease in its Oracle Solutions counterpart, although this can be attributed to the winding down of a large post-go-live engagement. Fernandez commented:

We continue to see strong overall EPM (Enterprise Performance Management) activity resulting from Oracle's re-establishment of their dedicated EPM sales force. Our SAP Solutions segment over-performed for the fourth quarter in a row as it closed several significant value-added reseller transactions, which strongly benefited the quarter. This increased reseller activity is directly attributable to our decision to expand our sales force in that group.

Gen AI everywhere

But it was to generative AI potential that most attention was turned in the CEO’s post-results announcement call with analysts as Fernandez declared:

We believe gen AI-enabled transformation is a generational opportunity that will fundamentally change the way companies operate as well as the way consulting services are sold and delivered. The gen AI platform capabilities of AI XPLR have now been extended with ZBrain's ability to orchestrate and build complex multi-agent workflows, which should allow us to compete strongly in this rapidly growing space. More importantly, what's most differentiating is the power of our combined end-to-end capability. AI XPLR's capability to dynamically ideate and evaluate agentic gen AI solutions with the advanced open-source orchestration capabilities of ZBrain. This capability allows us to serve clients from ideation to implementation in one fully-integrated platform. It also provides clients with a single platform that they can license to fully support their entire AI center of innovation.

Most importantly, clients are now moving from awareness and education activities around gen AI to actually spending money on budgeted projects, he added:

We continue to see gen AI opportunities emerge. We conducted hundreds of meetings with Global 2000 organizations from our introduction of AI XPLR earlier in the year. These demo meetings and conversations have provided us with valuable adoption insight along with the implementation concerns and limitations of our prospects. These initial meetings are now starting to become new gen AI-enabled transformation opportunities that position us to serve our clients strategically and broadly.

To meet those opportunities, Hackett continues to strengthen its AI arsenal. Fernandez cited as a case in point:

We also continue to innovate and make powerful improvements to AI XPLR. In fact, we will release a new version 3 during this first quarter. The most important of the enhancements in version 3 is our ability to dynamically simulate an organization's enterprise gen AI solutions by leveraging Hackett's proprietary IP to identify automation opportunities and related data source requirements at a work step level. This enables us to identify, design and evaluate meaningful AI use cases and identify the related AI agents required to build these solutions. Given the strategic access and proprietary and expanding platform capabilities of AI XPLR, it was natural for us to extend our AI implementation capabilities to be able to fully develop and implement gen AI solutions that we were identifying.

It was the same basic driver that led to the acquisition of Indian AI champion LeewayHertz last September, he added:

This acquisition also included a sophisticated gen AI orchestration platform, ZBrain, which we agreed to contribute into a joint venture with the LeewayHertz founder. The JV, which is to be named ZBrain, brings together the AI XPLR and ZBrain software platforms and will focus on licensing the platforms and creating what we believe to be a first-of-a-kind gen AI ideation through implementation software-as-a-service offering.

Exec focus

All told, the foundations are now in place for the next phase of a concerted generative AI push, argued Fernandez, with top tier executives as the target audience for advisory services:

There is no doubt that in just one year, our aggressive pivot to become the architects of our clients' gen AI journey is being well received and has significant value creation potential for our organization…We are now working on launching a premium gen AI solutioning advisory program to fully leverage our solutioning innovation and implementation knowledge from our platforms and clients' engagements that will be directly targeted and the program will be directly targeted to AI leaders, CIOs, and CTOs who require this knowledge.

The timing is right for all this, suggests Fernandez:

In 2025, we expect IT budgets to increase with increasing attention and allocations to the rapidly-emerging gen AI solutions and the related opportunities and threats it brings to all industries. While in 2024 gen AI budgets were primarily focused on developing awareness of AI, in 2025, you will see increasing amount of IT budgets specifically allocated to gen AI initiatives in high feasibility and high impact areas. We also expect to see an increasing investments in data quality and value initiatives that are critical to any gen AI strategy.

As for the recent attention that’s been given to China’s DeepSeek, that isn’t going to do any harm in focusing exec attention, he concluded:

I'll call it a wake-up call. I think is great news for end users and people that plan to adopt gen AI capabilities throughout these next few years.

My take

We see increasing activity. But more importantly, we see clients with budgeted 2025 initiatives planned, which really changes the engagement for us.

Hackett’s “aggressive pivot” towards gen AI services has been a work-in-progress, but it’s clear that Fernandez expects great things in the coming months:

We're better prepared than where we were a year ago, and clients don't need to be convinced about the gen AI opportunity, what it means to their industry…Once you're able to demonstrate value with a select or a few use cases or solutions as we refer to them, we believe that clients will continue to increase their spend in the category. So, look, it's very promising.

That’s the plan then. We’ll check back in on progress as the year progresses.

Satish Kumar, CEO and Co-Founder of Glider AI, shares, "We're revolutionizing talent acquisition and skills development within SAP by making it objective, efficient, and scalable. Combining AI and automation with real-world assessments and interviews ensures companies hire quality talent and develop skills that drive business growth."

We bring verified skills data into SAP SuccessFactors, turning raw talent insights into strategic workforce advantages. Post this

He further emphasizes Glider AI's unique offering to SAP SuccessFactors, "We bring verified skills data into SAP SuccessFactors, transforming raw talent insights into strategic workforce advantages. This empowers enterprises to reduce costs, speed up hiring, and build high-performing teams that deliver measurable business impact."

HR, TA, and Talent Management teams can explore Glider AI's workforce transformation capabilities with a 3-month starter package, including unlimited users, 100 skill assessments, and 100 interviews per month.

Interactive skill assessments verify real-world abilities for tech and non-tech roles with AI-driven rankings and fraud prevention for fair, data-backed hiring.

verify real-world abilities for tech and non-tech roles with AI-driven rankings and prevention for fair, data-backed hiring. AI-guided interviews generate role-specific questions, automate evaluations, and provide instant scorecards to streamline screening.

generate role-specific questions, automate evaluations, and provide instant scorecards to streamline screening. Live coding interviews assess developers in a real-world IDE with curated tasks and AI-proctored security for consistent, unbiased evaluations.

assess developers in a real-world IDE with curated tasks and AI-proctored security for consistent, unbiased evaluations. Skills benchmarking and upskilling identify gaps, track progress, and support employee growth through practice-based learning and certifications.

identify gaps, track progress, and support employee growth through practice-based learning and certifications. Automated hiring workflows reduce recruiter workload with AI-powered scheduling, video evaluations, fraud detection, and compliance management.

SAP Store, found at store.sap.com, delivers a simplified and connected digital customer experience for finding, trying, buying and renewing more than 2,300 solutions from SAP and its partners. There, customers can find the SAP solutions and SAP-validated solutions they need to grow their business. And for each purchase made through SAP Store, SAP will plant a tree.

Glider AI is a partner in the SAP PartnerEdge® program. The SAP PartnerEdge program provides the enablement tools, benefits and support to facilitate building high-quality, disruptive applications focused on specific business needs – quickly and cost-effectively.

Glider AI is a Skills Validation Platform™ that helps companies validate candidate and employee skills with AI-powered assessments and interviews. Glider AI enables businesses to find the talent they need and grow the talent they have while integrating seamlessly with SAP to bring efficiency and objectivity to hiring and talent development.

4.title: UK electrical utility seeks partner for £81M SAP overhaul as support deadline closes in
4.snippet: A UK electrical infrastructure biz is seeking a systems integrator to help it migrate from a 25-year-old SAP ERP system to the latest S/4HANA platform in a...
4.content:
A UK electrical infrastructure biz is seeking a systems integrator to help it migrate from a 25-year-old SAP ERP system to the latest S/4HANA platform in a contract set to be worth almost a quarter of its annual turnover.

In a project expected to accommodate integration with non-SAP applications and some custom development, Northern Ireland Electricity (NIE) Networks has published an invitation to tender for the replacement of its aging ECC system, first rolled out in 1999.

The £339.6 million ($427 million) revenue company, which was privatized in 1993, plans to replace the software with the latest ERP platform from SAP, but the tender documents suggest it is not migrating to the cloud or using the RISE with SAP program, the lift-shift-and-transform arrangement where the German vendor fronts deals with SIs and cloud providers.

However, a pre-qualification questionnaire states NIE is moving to the cloud but does not specify its favored route. The "commercial model is still to be agreed, including if this will be via SAP RISE or non-RISE on hyperscaler."

An indicative sum of £81 million ($102 million) is on the table for the system integrator contract, which could last four years plus two one-year extension periods.

Whoever considers bidding for the job should be prepared for a complex project. A market engagement notice published in October last year said the 25-year-old SAP ERP applications "form a fundamental platform in supporting the core NIE Networks business and market processes."

"Multiple internal non-SAP applications and external partner systems are integrated with the SAP system estate, working together to provide end-to-end business capabilities and overall compliance with regulatory, market, and statutory obligations," it said. Work is set to start in January 2026.

In the contract notice published this month, NIE Networks said that as well as the 1999 ECC implementation, SAP Business Objects (reporting and BI) and supplier relationship management was added in 2008.

In 2012, it made a "strategic investment" to implement a separate instance of utility application SAP IS-U and SAP Business Warehouse (data warehouse), "further adding to the utilization of SAP products and establishing a core technology platform on NIE Networks Ltd IT estate."

As well as grappling with the complexity of the project, any winning bidder will have to deal with the timeline.

Mainstream vendor support for ECC ends at the end of 2027, after which extended vendor support is available for a 2 percent premium, which does not provide product updates, although the vendor does provide patches and bug fixes.

"NIE Networks Ltd plans to upgrade to SAP S/4 HANA to ensure interoperability with current systems be maintained and to fully leverage new technologies and functionalities on an established platform, thus maintaining a stable and secure system within the company's IT estate," the company said.

The Register has asked NIE Networks why it has decided not to move to the cloud and use RISE with SAP, the vendor's preferred method for getting there. ®

6.title: Inetum Ignites UK&I Markets with its SAP Global Practice Expansion
6.snippet: Inetum UK&I becomes an SAP PE SELL Partner, offering a customer-centric approach and innovative SAP solutions. UK&I businesses gain access to Inetum's...
6.content:
Release date : Tue, 02/18/2025

Inetum's SAP Global Practice officially extends to the UK&I markets.

Inetum UK&I becomes an SAP PE SELL Partner, offering a customer-centric approach and innovative SAP solutions.

UK&I businesses gain access to Inetum's proven SAP expertise, a blend of local, nearshore, and offshore consulting capabilities, and a competitive, cost-effective service model.

With a proven track record of success across EMEA, Inetum brings its expertise, innovation, and customer-centric approach to the UK and Ireland (UK&I) markets, earning recognition as a Top 3 S/4HANA Public Cloud Partner and a Top 4 SAP Cloud Partner in the region.

What does this mean for UK&I businesses?

Access to Inetum’s proven SAP expertise across GROW, RISE, and AI programs

A powerful blend of local, nearshore, and offshore consulting capabilities

A highly competitive and cost-effective service model

A trusted SAP partner with a track record of delivering transformation at scale

The UK&I markets are home to some of the world's most technology-driven companies, always at the forefront of innovation and digital transformation. Inetum contributes to this dynamic ecosystem by delivering cutting-edge SAP solutions that have already brought remarkable success to its customers across Europe.

Kathy Quashie, CEO of Inetum UK&I and Growing Markets: ""We are delighted to extend our relationship with SAP in the UK and Ireland. This partnership allows us to continue delivering transformative change and digital impact, reinforcing our commitment to our clients. In these regions, businesses are focused on innovative solutions, HR/Finance transformation, and data management, which are vital to their growth. This collaboration also enables us to leverage our nearshore and offshore capabilities. With the UK being one of the largest AI markets globally, our work with SAP offers a significant opportunity to support clients on their digital journey and Agentic AI readiness."

Natalia Blanco, SAP Global Partner Manager at SAP: " We are delighted with this successful global partnership, which will strengthen Inetum’s presence across Europe, the Middle East, and Latin America, furthering our shared growth and success in key markets and industries. Inetum is always one step ahead in helping its customers accelerate the adoption of SAP’s industry best practices, crafted through collaboration to ensure the best fit in the market. That is why we're proud to have Inetum as an SAP PE SELL partner in the UK and Ireland."

Fiamma Ferrero, SVP, Global Practice Manager SAP at Inetum Solutions: “Our UK&I markets partnership highlights our team's dedication to delivering innovative, high value-added solutions and helps the customers achieve their business goals. We are poised to support our customers and prospects in their transformational projects involving ERP, enterprise data, and GenAI, allowing them to leverage the full spectrum of SAP innovations, particularly in the cloud. Additionally, this partnership strengthens our strategic relationships within SAP’s ecosystem and enables us to deploy innovative solutions for customers across different sectors. Inetum Solutions is thus positioned as an essential partner in these digital transformation projects.”

Leading the Way in SAP Digital Transformation

Inetum's commitment to excellence in SAP solutions was recently recognized with two prestigious awards at the SAP EMEA Partner Excellence Awards 2025 for Cloud Delivery and Human Capital Management. These awards underline Inetum's high performance in strategic areas and its commitment to delivering first-class services to its customers.

Looking ahead, Inetum has set itself the ambitious target of increasing its global SAP business by over 50% by 2027, and can count on its workforce exceeding 2,700 SAP consultants globally, with more than 400 certified consultants and over 800 certifications.

About Inetum

Inetum is a European leader in digital services. The team of 28,000 consultants and experts at Inetum strives every day to make a digital impact on businesses, public sector entities, and society. Inetum's solutions aim to contribute to the performance and innovation of its clients, as well as to the general interest. Present in 19 countries with a dense network of centers, Inetum collaborates with the main software manufacturers to face the challenges of digital transformation with proximity and flexibility. Driven by its ambition for growth and expansion, Inetum generated a turnover of 2.5 billion euros in 2023. For more information, visit www.inetum.com

For more information, please contact:

Inetum on Social Media:

Facebook / LinkedIn / YouTube / Instagram

7.title: From SAP ERP Projects to ERP Lifecycles
7.snippet: IgniteSAP explores how the shift toward the continuous improvement model in SAP services affects the careers of individual consultants.
7.content:
ERP “Lifecycles”

For years, SAP consulting worked in the following way: a company invests in a major ERP rollout, consultants configure and deploy the system, and once the project is completed, the system remains largely unchanged except for occasional maintenance or minor enhancements. Eventually, when the system is no longer meeting business needs, another large-scale upgrade or reimplementation occurs.

Organizations now view ERP as a continuously evolving system that must adapt to ongoing business and technology changes. This change affects how SAP solutions are designed and delivered, but also how SAP consultants structure their work, how ERP investments are budgeted, and how technical challenges are managed over time.

This article from IgniteSAP explores how the industry-wide shift toward the continuous improvement model in SAP services affects implementation practices and the careers of individual consultants.



Why Traditional ERP Projects Are Becoming Less Common

The primary driver behind this shift is the need for business agility. Companies can no longer afford to wait five or ten years for a major upgrade when market conditions, regulatory requirements, and technological advancements are changing constantly. Instead, they need continuous improvements that allow them to evolve their ERP systems in real time.

At the same time, SAP has moved away from the on-premise, big-bang upgrade model. With SAP S/4HANA Cloud and RISE with SAP, businesses don’t “own” ERP software in the traditional sense. Instead, they subscribe to a service where updates, new features, and optimizations are introduced several times a year rather than every few years.

On-premise instances of S/4HANA are still widely-used but the direction of travel for the industry is towards cloud-based SAP, and SAP consultants now support ongoing system evolution, performance tuning, and business process optimization, and they are expected to stay engaged long-term, helping businesses take advantage of new updates and capabilities as they become available.



How This Impacts SAP Project Costs and Consultant Billing Models

The financial structure of SAP projects has also changed. Previously, companies made large capital expenditures when purchasing software licenses and funding implementation projects. Now, with cloud-based ERP and subscription services, ERP costs are spread over time as operational expenditures, meaning that businesses allocate continuous budgets for incremental improvements, rather than securing massive funding rounds for periodic overhauls.

For SAP consultants, this is gradually leading to a reduction in large, high-fee implementation contracts in favor of long-term service agreements, retainers, and managed services contracts. Instead of billing for project-based deliverables, many SAP professionals are shifting to subscription-based consulting, ongoing system monitoring, and continuous advisory engagements.

This has also caused a shift in pricing models toward value-based consulting, where fees are tied to measurable business outcomes rather than billable hours or project milestones.

Consultants who adapt to this new reality by positioning themselves as ERP lifecycle advisors rather than project implementers will benefit from greater job security and consistent revenue streams. Those who continue relying on traditional project-based work may find fewer opportunities.



How SAP’s AI Strategy Is Reshaping ERP Lifecycles

Many of the manual tasks that SAP consultants once performed are now handled by AI-powered tools which can monitor, analyze, and suggest optimizations in real time.

Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, continuously learns from business data, identifying opportunities for automation, workflow improvements, and smarter decision-making. Similarly, SAP Signavio AI-Powered Process Insights allows organizations to assess how well their processes are performing and make data-driven refinements without needing external analysis.

For SAP consultants, this reduces the need for traditional configuration work, and at the same time, there is a growing demand for AI expertise, requiring consultants to train and fine-tune AI models rather than manually designing business processes. Organizations now expect consultants to drive business value through AI-driven ERP enhancements, transitioning from reactive system management to proactive ERP self-optimization.

In essence, the role of the SAP consultant is evolving from an ERP configuration specialist to an AI-enhanced business process advisor. Those who can effectively integrate AI into SAP lifecycles and guide businesses in leveraging these intelligent tools will be in the highest demand.



The Technical Challenges of Continuous ERP Evolution

While continuous ERP improvement offers many advantages, it also introduces new challenges that SAP consultants must address.

One of the biggest concerns is keeping up with frequent updates. In traditional on-premise ERP models, companies had years between major upgrades, allowing plenty of time for testing, validation, and change management. With SAP S/4HANA Cloud and other cloud-based SAP solutions, updates occur several times per year.

For SAP consultants, this means helping businesses manage update cycles without disrupting daily operations, testing and validating system changes before deployment, and ensuring that new features don’t break existing processes.

Consultants are also redesigning ERP architectures to be more flexible, avoiding heavy customizations that make future updates difficult.

Many organizations built heavily customized SAP systems in the past, making upgrades complex and risky. Now, with frequent updates, customization must rely on pre-configuration options and standardized implementation processes to optimize scalability and upgradability in clients’ systems.

Another major challenge is managing ERP security and compliance in a constantly evolving system. Businesses must ensure that frequent updates do not introduce security vulnerabilities or cause compliance risks, especially in regulated industries.



How This Affects SAP Consultant Career Earnings and Financial Opportunities

As the ERP consulting landscape moves from large, one-off implementations to continuous service models, the way SAP consultants earn and structure their careers is shifting.

For many SAP professionals, this transition means moving from fixed-scope project billing to retainer-based agreements or value-based pricing models. Rather than being compensated for hours worked, consultants are increasingly paid based on measurable business outcomes: such as process efficiency gains, automation effectiveness, or cost reductions enabled by SAP optimization.

This model offers greater financial stability, as SAP consultants who establish long-term client relationships enjoy recurring revenue streams rather than the uncertainty of securing new projects every few years.

It also introduces new issues, such as:

Consultants must continuously demonstrate value rather than delivering a completed system and moving on.

The demand for generalist SAP configuration work is declining, while expertise in process automation, AI integration, and ERP lifecycle strategy is becoming more lucrative.



How SAP BTP is Reshaping ERP Consulting Work

As companies adopt continuous ERP evolution, they are increasingly turning to SAP Business Technology Platform for integration, automation, and system flexibility. Instead of customizing SAP S/4HANA’s core system, businesses now extend and enhance their ERP capabilities through BTP’s modular, event-driven architecture.

For SAP consultants, this is where the high-value work is shifting. Expertise in SAP BTP is quickly becoming a key differentiator, as businesses seek professionals who can:

Develop event-driven ERP architectures that allow real-time data exchanges between SAP and third-party applications.

Implement process automation using tools like SAP Workflow Management and SAP iRPA (Intelligent Robotic Process Automation).

Help businesses transition away from legacy ERP customizations by leveraging BTP’s low-code/no-code development environment.

As SAP S/4HANA Cloud updates are rolled out frequently, businesses need consultants who understand how to maintain and extend their ERP systems without causing disruptions.



Career Specialization in the SAP Lifecycle Era

With ERP evolving into a continuous business function, SAP professionals must consider how they can differentiate themselves in this new landscape.

Some of the most promising career paths in the SAP ecosystem include:

AI-Driven ERP Optimization – Specializing in SAP Signavio Process Intelligence and machine learning for business process refinement.

SAP BTP Architecture & Integration – Helping businesses build scalable, event-driven ERP ecosystems using SAP Integration Suite and API-based workflows.

SAP Security & Compliance Advisory – Ensuring businesses remain compliant with evolving regulatory standards while implementing AI-driven threat detection and risk assessment solutions.

Consultants who focus on one of these specializations will find that demand for their expertise continues to grow.



Why Long-Term Advisory Roles Are the Future of SAP Consulting

Businesses now seek long-term ERP transformation partners who can guide them through ongoing adaptation and system enhancement.

This means SAP consultants must focus on ERP lifecycle management rather than discrete implementations, providing continuous advisory services and developing expertise in AI, automation, and integration.

SAP consulting firms are also changing their service models in response to this shift. Many firms are now offering subscription-based ERP consulting, where businesses pay for ongoing system support and advisory services, though hybrid deployment models are also a popular compromise with large customers who originally had extensive on-premise systems, so skills related to on-premise implementation will still have a place in the industry for some time yet.



How SAP Consultants Can Stay Ahead

The old model of SAP consulting, where consultants were brought in for a project, implemented a system, and then moved on, is rapidly becoming obsolete. A new SAP consulting landscape is emerging, where continuous improvement, automation, and AI-driven insights define how businesses manage their ERP environments.

The ability to adapt has never been more important. Professionals who align their careers with continuous ERP evolution will thrive, while those who cling to outdated project-based models may struggle to find opportunities

The future of SAP consulting will consist of helping businesses navigate an ERP journey that never truly ends. Those who recognize this shift and adjust their approach accordingly will find themselves at the forefront of SAP’s evolving digital landscape.

If you are an SAP professional looking for a new role in the SAP ecosystem our team of dedicated recruitment consultants can match you with your ideal employer and negotiate a competitive compensation package for your extremely valuable skills, so join our exclusive community at IgniteSAP.

8.content:
Venturi Wealth Management LLC increased its stake in SAP SE (NYSE:SAP - Free Report) by 24.8% in the 4th quarter, according to the company in its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The institutional investor owned 12,458 shares of the software maker's stock after acquiring an additional 2,474 shares during the period. Venturi Wealth Management LLC's holdings in SAP were worth $3,067,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.

Get SAP alerts: Sign Up

Several other large investors also recently added to or reduced their stakes in SAP. FMR LLC boosted its holdings in shares of SAP by 22.3% in the 3rd quarter. FMR LLC now owns 10,246,279 shares of the software maker's stock worth $2,347,422,000 after purchasing an additional 1,866,468 shares during the period. WCM Investment Management LLC purchased a new position in SAP during the fourth quarter worth $290,023,000. Principal Financial Group Inc. increased its position in SAP by 0.8% during the third quarter. Principal Financial Group Inc. now owns 611,572 shares of the software maker's stock valued at $140,111,000 after acquiring an additional 4,775 shares during the last quarter. JPMorgan Chase & Co. raised its stake in shares of SAP by 1.4% in the third quarter. JPMorgan Chase & Co. now owns 548,469 shares of the software maker's stock valued at $125,654,000 after acquiring an additional 7,667 shares during the period. Finally, Stifel Financial Corp lifted its holdings in shares of SAP by 12.5% in the 3rd quarter. Stifel Financial Corp now owns 210,804 shares of the software maker's stock worth $48,295,000 after acquiring an additional 23,352 shares during the last quarter.

Analysts Set New Price Targets

Several equities analysts recently commented on the stock. Royal Bank of Canada reiterated an "outperform" rating and set a $38.00 price target on shares of SAP in a report on Thursday, January 30th. JMP Securities upped their target price on SAP from $300.00 to $330.00 and gave the company a "market outperform" rating in a research note on Wednesday, January 29th. Barclays raised their price target on SAP from $283.00 to $286.00 and gave the stock an "overweight" rating in a research note on Thursday, January 30th. TD Cowen raised SAP from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating and upped their price objective for the company from $240.00 to $305.00 in a research report on Friday, January 17th. Finally, Kepler Capital Markets upgraded SAP from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research report on Wednesday, January 15th. Ten analysts have rated the stock with a buy rating, According to data from MarketBeat.com, the stock presently has an average rating of "Buy" and an average target price of $248.83.

Check Out Our Latest Research Report on SAP

SAP Stock Down 1.8 %

Shares of SAP traded down $5.06 during midday trading on Friday, reaching $282.87. 1,105,122 shares of the stock were exchanged, compared to its average volume of 1,028,502. The company has a market capitalization of $347.50 billion, a P/E ratio of 98.56, a PEG ratio of 4.72 and a beta of 1.23. The company has a current ratio of 1.12, a quick ratio of 1.10 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.16. SAP SE has a 52 week low of $175.08 and a 52 week high of $293.70. The company's 50 day moving average is $265.88 and its two-hundred day moving average is $241.18.

SAP (NYSE:SAP - Get Free Report) last issued its earnings results on Tuesday, January 28th. The software maker reported $1.49 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, missing the consensus estimate of $1.51 by ($0.02). SAP had a return on equity of 12.18% and a net margin of 9.17%. On average, sell-side analysts anticipate that SAP SE will post 6.55 earnings per share for the current year.

About SAP

SAP SE, together with its subsidiaries, provides applications, technology, and services worldwide. It offers SAP S/4HANA that provides software capabilities for finance, risk and project management, procurement, manufacturing, supply chain and asset management, and research and development; SAP SuccessFactors solutions for human resources, including HR and payroll, talent and employee experience management, and people and workforce analytics; and spend management solutions that covers direct and indirect spend, travel and expense, and external workforce management.
